message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Current Applications of Game Theory in Construction Engineering and Management Research: A Social Network Analysis Approach
Paper Abstract: Game theory provides a rigorous mathematical approach to evaluate and predict stakeholders' interactions. Even though the construction industry is rich with encounters among its stakeholders, construction engineering and management (CEM) research lacks a thorough investigation of game-theoretic applications. This paper presents an overview of the current game-theoretic models in CEM research, aiming to enhance the understanding of the applications of game theory in analyzing CEM strategic interactions within multiple application domains and project delivery systems (PDSs). The authors analyzed 87 CEM peer-reviewed publications employing game-theoretic models between 1998 and 2019. The analysis accounted for CEM application domain, involvement of stakeholders, PDS addressed, and type of game theoretic solution used in each publication. The authors performed a Social Network Analysis (SNA) of the current game-theoretic interactions, identifying literature trends and gaps to be addressed in future research. Unlike traditional literature review methods, SNA provides a quantitative approach in analyzing the existing body of knowledge. Research findings demonstrate the contributions of game theory in seven CEM applications (conflict resolution; bargaining and negotiations; allocation of cooperative benefits; governance and supervision; evolution of cooperation and trust; construction bidding; and risk allocation). Through SNA, the highest degree centrality levels were found in Owner-Contractor games in the context of CEM bidding, conflict resolution, as well as bargaining and negotiations. SNA also revealed the need for further investigation of interactions among CEM stakeholders within PDS other than the traditional Design-Bid-Build and Public-Private-Partnerships. Moreover, games featuring strategic alliances and supply chains of multiagents can provide more adequate reflections of actual interactions.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about game theory:

## Overview

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.(no content)It is now an umbrella term for the science of rational decision making in humans, animals, and computers.

## Historical Development

Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann.(no content)Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant. In the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.(no content)John Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.

## Applications and Recognition

Fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020, including most recently Paul Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson.(no content)In the 1970s, game theory was extensively applied in biology, largely as a result of the work of John Maynard Smith and his evolutionarily stable strategy.

Links: [{"title":"Design–bid–build","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Design–bid–build"},{"title":"Granary, Bristol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Granary,_Bristol"},{"title":"Design–build","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Design–build"},{"title":"Pre-construction services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pre-construction_services"},{"title":"Design–bid–build - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Design–bid–build#:~:text=Design–bid–build (or,and construction of a project."}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Design-Bid-Build:

## Overview

Design–bid–build (abbreviated D–B–B or D/B/B), also known as Design–tender or "design/tender," the traditional method, or hardbid, is a project delivery method in which the agency or owner contracts with separate entities for the design and construction of a project.

## The Three Main Phases

There are three main sequential phases to the design–bid–build delivery method. In the design phase, the owner retains an architect (or consulting engineer for infrastructure works) to design and produce bid documents, including construction drawings and technical specifications, on which various general contractors will in turn bid to construct the project.

## Key Characteristics

Design–bid–build is the traditional method for project delivery and differs in several substantial aspects from design–build.(no content)In contrast to design–bid–build, design–build relies on a single point of responsibility contract and is used to minimize risks for the project owner and to reduce the delivery schedule by overlapping the design phase and construction phase of a project.

## Advantages and Considerations

Design-bid-build ensures fairness to potential bidders and improves decision making by the owner by providing a range of potential options. It also identifies new potential contractors and assists the owner in establishing reasonable prices for the project.

Links: [{"title":"Public–private partnership","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public–private_partnership"},{"title":"Public/social/private partnership - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public/social/private_partnership"},{"title":"Public–private partnership in Canada - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public-private_partnerships_in_Canada"},{"title":"Global public–private partnership","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_public–private_partnership"},{"title":"Public–private partnerships in the United States","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public–private_partnerships_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Public–public partnership - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public%E2%80%93public_partnership"},{"title":"Template:Public-private partnership - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Public-private_partnership"},{"title":"Public-Private Partnership for Justice Reform in Afghanistan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public-Private_Partnership_for_Justice_Reform_in_Afghanistan"},{"title":"Category:Public–private partnership - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Public%E2%80%93private_partnership"},{"title":"Public–private partnerships in India - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Private_Partnership_in_India"}]

Here's comprehensive information about public-private partnerships (PPPs):

## Definition and Overview

A public–private partnership (PPP, 3P, or P3) is a long-term arrangement between a government and private sector institutions.(no content)Typically, it involves private capital financing government projects and services up-front, and then drawing revenues from taxpayers and/or users for profit over the course of the PPP contract.

## Key Characteristics

In PPPs, the ownership of the project is shared, and the heart of a PPP is the sharing of risks and profits.(no content)PPPs have been employed for building, equipping, operating and maintaining schools, hospitals, transport systems, and water and sewerage systems.

## Historical Development

Contemporary "public–private partnerships" came into being around the end of the 20th century.(no content)In 1992, the Conservative government of John Major in the United Kingdom introduced the private finance initiative (PFI), the first systematic program aimed at encouraging public–private partnerships.(no content)The late 20th and early 21st century saw a clear trend toward governments across the globe making greater use of various PPP arrangements.

## Global Usage

Public–private partnerships have been implemented in multiple countries and are primarily used for infrastructure projects.(no content)While initiated in first world countries, PPPs immediately received significant attention in developing countries because the PPP model promised to bring new sources of funding for infrastructure projects in transition economies, which could translate into jobs and economic growth.

Here's comprehensive information about public-private partnerships (PPPs):

## Definition and Overview

A public–private partnership (PPP, 3P, or P3) is a long-term arrangement between a government and private sector institutions.(no content)Typically, it involves private capital financing government projects and services up-front, and then drawing revenues from taxpayers and/or users for profit over the course of the PPP contract.

## Key Characteristics

In PPPs, the ownership of the project is shared, and the heart of a PPP is the sharing of risks and profits.(no content)PPPs have been employed for building, equipping, operating and maintaining schools, hospitals, transport systems, and water and sewerage systems.

## Historical Development

Contemporary "public–private partnerships" came into being around the end of the 20th century.(no content)In 1992, the Conservative government of John Major in the United Kingdom introduced the private finance initiative (PFI), the first systematic program aimed at encouraging public–private partnerships.(no content)The late 20th and early 21st century saw a clear trend toward governments across the globe making greater use of various PPP arrangements.

## Global Usage

Public–private partnerships have been implemented in multiple countries and are primarily used for infrastructure projects.(no content)While initiated in first world countries, PPPs immediately received significant attention in developing countries because the PPP model promised to bring new sources of funding for infrastructure projects in transition economies, which could translate into jobs and economic growth.

Saltzman Institute of War and Peace Studies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center_for_International_Conflict_Resolution"},{"title":"Edit conflict - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edit_conflict"}]

Here are the web search results for "conflict resolution":

## Definition and Overview

Conflict resolution is conceptualized as the methods and processes involved in facilitating the peaceful ending of conflict and retribution.(no content)Committed group members attempt to resolve group conflicts by actively communicating information about their conflicting motives or ideologies to the rest of group and by engaging in collective negotiation.

## Methods and Processes

A wide range of methods and procedures for addressing conflict exist, including negotiation, mediation, mediation-arbitration, diplomacy, and creative peacebuilding.

## Conflict Resolution Styles

Five styles for conflict management, as identified by Thomas and Kilmann, are: competing, compromising, collaborating, avoiding, and accommodating.(no content)The cooperation, integration, confrontation or problem-solving conflict style is typically used when an individual has elevated interests in their own outcomes as well as in the outcomes of others. During conflict, cooperators collaborate with others in an effort to find an amicable solution that satisfies all parties involved in the conflict.(no content)According to the literature on conflict resolution, a cooperative conflict resolution style is recommended above all others.

## Orientations to Conflict

There are three orientations to conflict: lose-lose, win-lose, and win-win. The win-win orientation is one of the most essential concepts to conflict resolution. A win-win solution arrived at by integrative bargaining may be close to optimal for both parties.

Links: [{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Social network analysis software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis_software"},{"title":"International Network for Social Network Analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Network_for_Social_Network_Analysis"},{"title":"Social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network"},{"title":"Social network analysis in criminology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis_in_criminology"},{"title":"Dynamic network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_network_analysis"},{"title":"Semantic social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_social_network"},{"title":"Network homophily - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_homophily"},{"title":"Cognitive social structures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_social_structures"},{"title":"Duocentric social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duocentric_social_network"}]

Here are the search results for "social network analysis":

## Overview

Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory.(no content)It characterizes networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

## Applications

Examples of social structures commonly visualized through social network analysis include social media networks, meme proliferation, information circulation, friendship and acquaintance networks, business networks, knowledge networks, difficult working relationships, collaboration graphs, kinship, disease transmission, and sexual relationships.

## Visualization

These networks are often visualized through sociograms in which nodes are represented as points and ties are represented as lines. These visualizations provide a means of qualitatively assessing networks by varying the visual representation of their nodes and edges to reflect attributes of interest.

## Key Metrics

Metrics encountered in social network analysis include those measuring the size, the nature of connections between members being analyzed, distribution, and segmentation - including subsets such as multiplexity, propinquity, density, centrality, and cohesion.

## Historical Development

Social network analysis has its theoretical roots in the work of early sociologists such as Georg Simmel and Émile Durkheim, who wrote about the importance of studying patterns of relationships that connect social actors.

Links: [{"title":"Supply chain management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply_chain_management"},{"title":"Supply chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply_chain"},{"title":"Supply-chain-management software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply-chain-management_software"},{"title":"Global supply chain management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_supply_chain_management"},{"title":"Association for Supply Chain Management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_for_Supply_Chain_Management"},{"title":"Supply Chain Management Review - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply_Chain_Management_Review"},{"title":"Category:Supply chain management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Supply_chain_management"},{"title":"Journal of Supply Chain Management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Supply_Chain_Management"},{"title":"Demand-chain management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demand-chain_management"},{"title":"Military supply-chain management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_supply-chain_management"}]

I've completed a web search for "supply chain management." Here are the key findings:

## Definition

Supply chain management (SCM) deals with a system of procurement (purchasing raw materials/components), operations management, logistics and marketing channels, through which raw materials can be developed into finished products and delivered to their end customers.

## Core Objectives

Supply chain management focuses on the optimization of the flow of goods within the supply chain's distribution channels to ensure efficiency.(no content)More specifically, SCM involves "design, planning, execution, control, and monitoring of supply chain activities with the objective of creating net value, building a competitive infrastructure, leveraging worldwide logistics, synchronising supply with demand and measuring performance globally".

## Key Activities

SCM encompasses the integrated planning and execution of processes required to optimize the flow of materials, information and capital in functions that broadly include demand planning, sourcing, production, inventory management and logistics—or storage and transportation.

## Current Focus Areas

Current research in supply chain management is concerned with topics related to resilience, sustainability, and risk management, among others.

## History

In 1982, Keith Oliver, a consultant at Booz Allen Hamilton, introduced the term "supply chain management" to the public domain in an interview for the Financial Times.

I've completed a web search for "supply chain management." Here are the key findings:

## Definition

Supply chain management (SCM) deals with a system of procurement (purchasing raw materials/components), operations management, logistics and marketing channels, through which raw materials can be developed into finished products and delivered to their end customers.

## Core Objectives

Supply chain management focuses on the optimization of the flow of goods within the supply chain's distribution channels to ensure efficiency.(no content)More specifically, SCM involves "design, planning, execution, control, and monitoring of supply chain activities with the objective of creating net value, building a competitive infrastructure, leveraging worldwide logistics, synchronising supply with demand and measuring performance globally".

## Key Activities

SCM encompasses the integrated planning and execution of processes required to optimize the flow of materials, information and capital in functions that broadly include demand planning, sourcing, production, inventory management and logistics—or storage and transportation.

## Current Focus Areas

Current research in supply chain management is concerned with topics related to resilience, sustainability, and risk management, among others.

## History

In 1982, Keith Oliver, a consultant at Booz Allen Hamilton, introduced the term "supply chain management" to the public domain in an interview for the Financial Times.

Web search results for query: "bargaining negotiation"

Links: [{"title":"Bargaining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bargaining"},{"title":"Bargaining power - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bargaining_power"},{"title":"Leverage (negotiation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leverage_(negotiation)"},{"title":"List of books about negotiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_books_about_negotiation"},{"title":"Collaborative bargaining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_bargaining"},{"title":"Negotiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negotiation"},{"title":"Cooperative bargaining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_bargaining"},{"title":"Automated negotiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_negotiation"},{"title":"Plea bargain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plea_bargain"},{"title":"Mutual Gains Approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_Gains_Approach"}]

Here are the search results for "bargaining negotiation":

## Definition and Overview

In social sciences, bargaining or haggling is a type of negotiation in which the buyer and seller of a good or service debate the price or nature of a transaction.(no content)If the bargaining produces agreement on terms, the transaction takes place.

## Types of Bargaining

**Integrative Bargaining**: Integrative bargaining (also called "interest-based bargaining," "win-win bargaining") is a negotiation strategy in which parties collaborate to find a "win-win" solution to their dispute and focuses on developing mutually beneficial agreements based on the interests of the disputants.

**Distributive Negotiation**: Distributive negotiation (also known as Win-lose game) attempts to distribute a "fixed pie" of benefits and operates under zero-sum conditions, where it is assumed that any gain made by one party will be at the expense of the other; haggling over prices on an open market, as in the purchase of a car or home, is an example of distributive negotiation.

**Cooperative Bargaining**: Cooperative bargaining is a process in which two people decide how to share a surplus that they can jointly generate.

**Collaborative Bargaining**: Collaborative bargaining is a style of negotiation which recognises the interests of the other party and emphasises cooperation between them.

## Bargaining Power

Bargaining power is the relative ability of parties in a negotiation to exert influence over each other in order to achieve favourable terms in an agreement.(no content)This power is derived from various factors such as each party's alternatives to the current deal, the value of what is being negotiated, and the urgency of reaching an agreement.

Web search results for query: "strategic alliance"

Links: [{"title":"Strategic alliance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_alliance"},{"title":"Strategic partnership - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_partnership"},{"title":"Strategic Content Alliance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_Content_Alliance"},{"title":"Category:Strategic alliances - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Strategic_alliances"},{"title":"Cooperative strategy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_strategy"},{"title":"China–Russia relations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China–Russia_relations"},{"title":"Rhine-Main-Universities - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhine-Main-Universities"},{"title":"Alliance of the periphery - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alliance_of_the_periphery"},{"title":"Strategic communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_communication"},{"title":"FinTech Alliance PH - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FinTech_Alliance_PH"}]

## Search Results for "Strategic Alliance"

I found comprehensive information about strategic alliances. Here's what the search revealed:

### Definition and Basic Concept

A strategic alliance is an agreement between two or more parties to pursue a set of agreed upon objectives needed while remaining independent organizations.(no content)The alliance is a cooperation or collaboration which aims for a synergy where each partner hopes that the benefits from the alliance will be greater than those from individual efforts.

### Key Characteristics

The alliance often involves technology transfer (access to knowledge and expertise), economic specialization, shared expenses and shared risk.(no content)Typically, two companies form a strategic alliance when each possesses one or more business assets or have expertise that will help the other by enhancing their businesses.(no content)In a strategic alliance, each company maintains its autonomy while gaining a new opportunity.

### Benefits and Purposes

A strategic alliance could help a company develop a more effective process, expand into a new market or develop an advantage over a competitor, among other possibilities.(no content)Partners may provide the strategic alliance with resources such as products, distribution channels, manufacturing capability, project funding, capital equipment, knowledge, expertise, or intellectual property.

### Types of Strategic Alliances

There are three types of strategic alliances. A joint venture is a shared equity firm wherein the participant commit the same quantity of resources, this means that this legally independent new company share resources, capabilities and risks to achieve a competitive advantage.

Web search results for query: "risk allocation"

Links: [{"title":"Risk parity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Risk_parity"},{"title":"Predation risk allocation hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Predation_risk_allocation_hypothesis"},{"title":"Asset allocation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asset_allocation"},{"title":"Risk-adjusted return on capital - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Risk-adjusted_return_on_capital"},{"title":"Capital allocation line - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capital_allocation_line"},{"title":"Portfolio optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portfolio_optimization"},{"title":"Efficient frontier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Efficient_frontier"},{"title":"Modern portfolio theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_portfolio_theory"},{"title":"Structured trade and commodity finance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structured_trade_and_commodity_finance"},{"title":"The Missing Billionaires - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Missing_Billionaires"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about risk allocation:

## Overview

Risk allocation is an approach to investment management which focuses on allocation of risk, usually defined as volatility, rather than allocation of capital. This is distinct from traditional capital allocation methods.

## Key Concepts

**Risk Parity Approach**: When asset allocations are adjusted to the same risk level, the risk parity portfolio can achieve a higher Sharpe ratio and can be more resistant to market downturns than the traditional portfolio.(no content)Risk parity attempts to equalize risk by allocating funds to a wider range of categories such as stocks, government bonds, credit-related securities and inflation hedges, while maximizing gains through financial leveraging.

**Asset Allocation**: More broadly, asset allocation is the implementation of an investment strategy that attempts to balance risk versus reward by adjusting the percentage of each asset in an investment portfolio according to the investor's risk tolerance, goals and investment time frame.

## Business Applications

In corporate and banking contexts, for risk management purposes, the main goal of allocating capital to individual business units is to determine the bank's optimal capital structure, and this use of capital based on risk improves the capital allocation across different functional areas of banks, insurance companies, or any business in which capital is placed at risk for an expected return above the risk-free rate.

Risk allocation is fundamental to modern portfolio management and helps investors and institutions optimize their exposure to various types of risk.

In corporate and banking contexts, for risk management purposes, the main goal of allocating capital to individual business units is to determine the bank's optimal capital structure, and this use of capital based on risk improves the capital allocation across different functional areas of banks, insurance companies, or any business in which capital is placed at risk for an expected return above the risk-free rate.

Risk allocation is fundamental to modern portfolio management and helps investors and institutions optimize their exposure to various types of risk.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about risk allocation:

## Overview

Risk allocation is an approach to investment management which focuses on allocation of risk, usually defined as volatility, rather than allocation of capital. This is distinct from traditional capital allocation methods.

## Key Concepts

**Risk Parity Approach**: When asset allocations are adjusted to the same risk level, the risk parity portfolio can achieve a higher Sharpe ratio and can be more resistant to market downturns than the traditional portfolio.(no content)Risk parity attempts to equalize risk by allocating funds to a wider range of categories such as stocks, government bonds, credit-related securities and inflation hedges, while maximizing gains through financial leveraging.

**Asset Allocation**: More broadly, asset allocation is the implementation of an investment strategy that attempts to balance risk versus reward by adjusting the percentage of each asset in an investment portfolio according to the investor's risk tolerance, goals and investment time frame.

## Business Applications

In corporate and banking contexts, for risk management purposes, the main goal of allocating capital to individual business units is to determine the bank's optimal capital structure, and this use of capital based on risk improves the capital allocation across different functional areas of banks, insurance companies, or any business in which capital is placed at risk for an expected return above the risk-free rate.

Risk allocation is fundamental to modern portfolio management and helps investors and institutions optimize their exposure to various types of risk.

message_text:
Excellent! All tasks have been completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey
- This paper presents an overview of game-theoretic models in construction engineering and management research, analyzing 87 peer-reviewed publications from 1998-2019.

**Key Entities Identified:** 9 triples extracted and validated

The analysis identified the following key concepts and methodologies from the paper:

1. **Game theory** - The core mathematical framework used to analyze stakeholder interactions
2. **Social network analysis** - The quantitative analytical method for identifying literature trends
3. **Conflict resolution** - One of 7 key CEM application areas
4. **Negotiation** - Bargaining and negotiations as a primary application
5. **Risk parity** - Representing risk allocation applications
6. **Design-bid-build** - Traditional project delivery system examined
7. **Public-private partnership** - Key PDS with research gaps identified
8. **Supply chain management** - Highlighted as an area needing future investigation
9. **Strategic alliance** - Identified as an important gap for future research

All triples have been validated against Wikipedia URLs and comply with the requirements:
- Paper is classified as "survey" ✓
- All 9 triples have proper entity types (7 concepts, 1 method, 1 task) ✓
- All triples use the "uses" relation (survey papers build on existing work) ✓
- All Wikipedia URLs are valid and accessible ✓

Sources:
